metadata.title: Extending
metadata.description:
Packer is designed to be extensible. Because the surface area for workloads is
infinite, Packer supports plugins for builders, provisioners, and
post-processors.

running application, Packer runs each plugin as a `,mdx("em",{parentName:"p"},`separate application`),`.

launching and cleaning up the plugin processes.`),mdx("h2",{"id":"plugin-development-basics"},mdx("a",{parentName:"h2","className":"__permalink-h","href":"#plugin-development-basics","aria-label":"plugin development basics permalink"},`\xbb`),`Plugin Development Basics`),mdx("p",null,`The components that can be created and used in a Packer plugin are builders,

`)),mdx("p",null,`By opening an integration request, you are asking a member of the to Packer team to review your plugin integration configuration, plugin documentation,
and, finally, to open an internal pull-request to finalize the integration setup. `),mdx("p",null,`Plugin integrations will be listed as a `,mdx("a",{parentName:"p","href":"/packer/integrations"},`Packer Integration`),`, with details on how to install and use your the plugin. `),mdx("p",null,`Plugin integrations, once deployed, can be updated manually, or automatically upon a new release, by the plugin authors. Changes to the defined documentation structure
or parent repository should be communicated to the Packer team to ensure a working integration pipeline. `),mdx("h2",{"id":"plugin-development-tips-and-faqs"},mdx("a",{parentName:"h2","className":"__permalink-h","href":"#plugin-development-tips-and-faqs","aria-label":"plugin development tips and faqs permalink"},`\xbb`),`Plugin Development Tips and FAQs`),mdx("h3",{"id":"working-examples"},mdx("a",{parentName:"h3","className":"__permalink-h","href":"#working-examples","aria-label":"working examples permalink"},`\xbb`),`Working Examples`),mdx("p",null,`Here's a non-exhaustive list of Packer plugins that you can check out:`),mdx("ul",null,mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},mdx("a",{parentName:"li","href":"https://github.com/hashicorp/packer-plugin-docker"},`github.com/hashicorp/packer-plugin-docker`)),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},mdx("a",{parentName:"li","href":"https://github.com/exoscale/packer-plugin-exoscale"},`github.com/exoscale/packer-plugin-exoscale`)),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},mdx("a",{parentName:"li","href":"https://github.com/sylviamoss/packer-plugin-comment"},`github.com/sylviamoss/packer-plugin-comment`))),mdx("p",null,`Looking at their code will give you good examples.`),mdx("h3",{"id":"naming-conventions"},mdx("a",{parentName:"h3","className":"__permalink-h","href":"#naming-conventions","aria-label":"naming conventions permalink"},`\xbb`),`Naming Conventions`),mdx("p",null,`It is standard practice to name the resulting plugin application in the format
of `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},`packer-plugin-NAME`),`. For example, if you're building a new builder for
CustomCloud, it would be standard practice to name the resulting plugin
`,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},`packer-plugin-customcloud`),`. This naming convention helps users identify the
scope of a plugin.`),mdx("h3",{"id":"testing-plugins"},mdx("a",{parentName:"h3","className":"__permalink-h","href":"#testing-plugins","aria-label":"testing plugins permalink"},`\xbb`),`Testing Plugins`),mdx("p",null,`Making your unpublished plugin available to Packer is possible by either:`),mdx("ul",null,mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},`Starting Packer from the directory where the plugin binary is located.`),mdx("li",{parentName:"ul"},`Putting the plugin binary in the same directory as Packer.`)),mdx("p",null,`In both these cases, if the binary is called `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},`packer-plugin-myawesomecloud`),` and
defines an `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},`ebs`),` builder then you will be able to use an `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},`myawesomecloud-ebs`),`
builder or source without needing to have a `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},`required_plugin`),` block.`),mdx("p",null,`This is extremely useful during development.`),mdx("h3",{"id":"distributing-plugins"},mdx("a",{parentName:"h3","className":"__permalink-h","href":"#distributing-plugins","aria-label":"distributing plugins permalink"},`\xbb`),`Distributing Plugins`),mdx("p",null,`We recommend that you use a tool like the GoReleaser in order to cross-compile
your plugin for every platform that Packer supports, since Go applications are
platform-specific. If you have created your plugin from the
`,mdx("a",{parentName:"p","href":"https://github.com/hashicorp/packer-plugin-scaffolding"},`packer-plugin-scaffolding`),`
repo, simply tagging a commit and pushing the tag to GitHub will correctly build
and release the binaries using GoReleaser.`))};MDXContent.isMDXComponent=true;

metadata.title: Packer by HashiCorp
metadata.description: Packer helps you create golden images for multiple platforms from a single source configuration.

integrationsConfig.description: A curated collection of official, partner, and community Packer Integrations.
